website_summaries.verdict: A small starter that puts out big sparks, but you need to know what you're doing. Includes some useful emergency features.
pros: Includes emergency whistle, waterproof tinder storage container
Connecting lanyard makes sure you don't lose the two pieces
cons: Plastic components are not very durable
Tinder storage department is very small

customer_reviews.title: Once you scrape off the coating on the rod it works great!!!
customer_reviews.text: What a great idea! This tool is very practical and easy to use. It should have instructions to make sure you scrape through the coating on the Ferrocerium rod before expecting to see any sparks though. Initially sparks were not produced but once we used the sharp edge of the striker and firmly pushed down on the rod while striking, the coating scraped off and the sparks started flying. If you purchased one and think it does not work, just employ the above simple technique and you are off to sending plenty of sparks to light a cotton ball for fire starting. I am going to keep one with my camping gear and in the car.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Disappointed
customer_reviews.text: Impossible to use and poorly made. There is an orange a ring I guess that is supposed to seal that unit which constantly falls off when you try to use it. There is a cap on the back to hold "tender" which also falls off very easily. Generating sparks is nearly impossible regardless of the amount of force used and with every possible technique we could come up with. Recipient of this Christmas gift was very disappointed.
customer_reviews.author: Spendstoomuchonamazon

customer_reviews.title: Mine doesn’t work
customer_reviews.text: Worthless. Scraped the black coating off and then tried to spark and.....nothing. I had to scrape and scrape and only occasionally got a minor spark. I thought I had lost my touch so I got out my Swedish Light My Fire knife (has ferro rod in the handle) and was producing nice sparks on every stroke. The striker for the BG has a nice sharp edge. The rod composition must be the problem.
customer_reviews.author: Fuzz

customer_reviews.title: Need to test more to further review.
customer_reviews.text: I only used this product twice before it was stolen out of my vehicle. I hope that the person's who needed it got a lot of use out of it. If you have watched the Bear Grylls show you see him take the device and create sparks to create a fire out of fine/lightweight/flammable vegetation. It was pretty easy to use, but I would like to actually run more tests with it to fully rate it. Especially when the unit is wet.
customer_reviews.author: Jamison

customer_reviews.title: Ready for You vs. Wild
customer_reviews.text: Okay, maybe I'm not on the level of Bear Grylls to actually take on the wild, but watching him use this product on his show inspired me to start fires while camping a whole new way. This product works really well and is easy to use. It works well in high humidity and has a condensed spark spray, which is good when in a dry area. Already family of avid campers are following our lead in purchasing this fire starter after seeing it in action.
customer_reviews.author: BWhitley

customer_reviews.title: Horrible can't be actual Gerber product.
customer_reviews.text: Like the other user wrote. This has to be a cheap knock off. Item Broke the first time using it. It's inferior in quality and unbelievably cheap. The center Flint rod flew off and the center of the handle cracked while trying to test out.The top cover that stores the cotton won't stay on after opening. The seal also came off and when I tried to close both pieces back together it does not properly close together as well. I am Really disappointed in the product. This can't be an official Gerber product. I am returning back.Rest assured it's more than likely a Chinese knock off.
customer_reviews.author: Art Flores

customer_reviews.title: Good
customer_reviews.text: I've had many fero rods over the years but this one has got to be the best.. the quality and quantity of sparks it gives off is just great... There are definitely better ones out there that I've seen but for this price it an excellent choice in my opinion.
customer_reviews.author: Wyatt

customer_reviews.title: Not the best Gerber product.
customer_reviews.text: I’m a big Gerber fan and I’ve been using Gerber product for over 15 years, but I can’t recommend this fire starter. Visually it looks impressive and it feels nice in my hand. The thing I didn’t like was the length of the fire starter stick. It was too short for my liking. I had to do multiple swipe to get enough sparks to start a fire. I’ve tried it with another brand with a longer stick and it took 1/3 of the swipe to start a fire. If Gerber makes one with a longer stick, I might consider getting another one.
customer_reviews.author: sannamarlee

customer_reviews.title: Good fire steel!
customer_reviews.text: I am not normally a fan of Bear Grylls endorsed products as they are typically junk. This one actually works fairly well. The fire steel generates decent sparks. The included striker is easy to use. The two halves combine to form a waterproof cover to prevent the fire steel from getting wet. The lanyard can be tightened to help hold those ends together. There is a small waterproof container that holds some cotton balls. The small whistle is ok. The fire steel is a little heavy, but it works.
customer_reviews.author: KfillyTop Contributor: Camping

customer_reviews.title: Meh
customer_reviews.text: I've found better ferro rods for cheaper that I liked more  I actually found this a little difficult to use . I tried to practice in a non-survival situation and I was really struggling trying to use the "tinder" included with just a small amount of wind. I believe I actually gave up and that was why I purchased the other rod. If you're more skilled with a fire starter, this might be find, but I'd look for a rod that it is a little longer.
customer_reviews.author: Michael Gardner

customer_reviews.title: Not Gerber.. Cheap knock off!
customer_reviews.text: I ordered this item because it was advertised as a Gerber. I received a cheap knock off that will not even throw a spark. I have included a picture of the item I received. It went straight into the trash after about 5 min. of trying to make it work. Very disappointing!
customer_reviews.author: James M.

customer_reviews.title: Very pleased with this fire starter.
customer_reviews.text: This works really well. At first, I was upset as I couldn't get a single spark out of the damn thing, but then I realized that there's a black paint-like coating over the ferrocerium rod which I was not aware of. After peeling away the black paint using the other end, I was able to get spark that actually last a pretty long time relative to other magnesium flint fire starters I've owned. My favorite part of this product, and the real reason I bought it is the water proof storage inside of the handle which I've stuffed with cotton balls coated with petrolium jelly. Overall, very pleased with this fire starter.
customer_reviews.author: Ubaldo B.

customer_reviews.title: Dissappointed
customer_reviews.text: Pro, durable materials. Cons, Don't be in a hurry to start a fire, you WILL work at trying to get a spark off this one, big orange rubber seal if for waterproofing still leaves gaps between unit plugins and fall off when units are pulled apart, end cap pops off to easy that hold a cotton ball.
customer_reviews.author: Yme

customer_reviews.title: Worked Pretty well for teaching my kids. And they had tons of fun learning how to use it.
customer_reviews.text: Very nice product, good price. I didn't read the instructions. Probably should. I found that if you hold and use the striker like a knife sharpening a stick I got WAY more sparks. I had a hard time not giving this a five star rating. The handles made it easy enough that my kids could generate enough force to get decent sparks. Far easier to get good sparks than the Swedish Fire Steel which I also purchased. Therefore I judge this fire steel to be a fair bit softer then the Swedish Firesteel.
customer_reviews.author: CAFelix

customer_reviews.title: great
customer_reviews.text: tried it out, works well, just make sure to bring cotton or really good fire starter leaves... initial scratch might startle you...
customer_reviews.author: Jose

customer_reviews.title: Cool!
customer_reviews.text: Works and sparks great but I only give it 4 stars because I lost in a race vs a lighter. lol. It sparks great and feels like a sturdy tool but you definitely need some very flammable material like the cotton balls it comes with in order to light. Overall, I am probably just naive thinking that I should be able to start standard fires with this without some sort of cotton balls or something but I tried with moss and pine straw and those wouldn't catch from the sparks this puts off.
customer_reviews.author: Samuel North

customer_reviews.title: Great gift for son
customer_reviews.text: My son loves Bear Grylls and this is the perfect firestarter to pack around with him. We've already used it and started a fire with it. It comes with a little pocket survival guide that's great for a 10-year old to learn. This is a great product.
customer_reviews.author: MoBarbs

customer_reviews.title: Quality build, should last a long time.
customer_reviews.text: The package was beat up but the content is sealed, thus unused. Solid item. expect it to last a long time. Bought this for emergency, so hoping to not need to use it ever. Paid eight dollars, seems like good value.
customer_reviews.author: Tickles

customer_reviews.title: Works as intended
customer_reviews.text: Well worth $10. You can certainly get fire starting kits and ferro rods cheaper than this, but this is more of a total package. It throws off sparks that make starting a fire pretty painless; especially if you're using an accelerant on your tinder (e.g. petroleum jelly soaked cotton balls). It's a solid construction out of good materials and it's a really great design with a small footprint. I especially love the small compartment for storing tinder. The whistle that comes with it works just fine, but it's just a bonus. If your purchase hinges solely on the whistle, then you're probably looking for the wrong product to begin with.
customer_reviews.author: Jared

customer_reviews.title: Overkill and heavy
customer_reviews.text: Personally, I find this very well constructed item too heavy. Granted, it gives a very firm grip to produce sparks, even with gloves on - And it produces a lot of sparks ! But, as I mentioned, it is heavy and there is no magnesium built in - only a tiny compartment - waterproof we hope - that holds a small amount of cotton. I must say, after trying both systems, that I prefer the magnesium stick-and-flint type, where you can scrape off a certain amount of magnesium and get the initial fire going that way.
customer_reviews.author: Jacob J.

customer_reviews.title: Works well
customer_reviews.text: I thought it looked a bit over the top when I first got it but in use it just works REALLY well. I mean it's Bear Grylls he wouldn't put his name on it if it wasn't rugged, light and a common sense way to start a fire even in bad conditions for firemaking
customer_reviews.author: Draomin

customer_reviews.title: Reliable, lightweight,
customer_reviews.text: Son and grandson are outdoorsy types. I love to give them things they may need out in the woods. This is stout and reliable and can be worn on a belt or backpack. I feel better knowing that they will always be able to light a fire for warmth, Security, or alarm.
customer_reviews.author: Native Texan I

customer_reviews.title: Everyone should have one.
customer_reviews.text: Can’t wait to put this to use when I go camping or hiking.
customer_reviews.author: lauren

customer_reviews.title: Great! Easy to grip!
customer_reviews.text: Bought this as a gift for my husband who wants to explore survival camping and he loves it. The handles make it easy to hold and grip for striking. It doesn't seem to work the first few strikes, but not sure this is the issue of the fire starter or us. Sometimes it seems the strings get in the way on occasion but overall has been a fun camping activity for us.
customer_reviews.author: Brandi

customer_reviews.title: Works well but could be better...
customer_reviews.text: The functionality of this firestarting stick is great. It truly makes a nice, hot spark and is easy to get tinder aflame. The fit/finish needs improvement. It is HARD to get apart. There is supposedly a small storage compartment in it, but it is so incredibly difficult to get to that its useless. Occasionally if you don't have the steel in JUST the right spot you also cant get it closed. Good to throw into a survival bag but definitely has the ability to be better designed. I guess i didn't try drinking my pee to see if that would help - it's what Bear Grylls would do afterall...
customer_reviews.author: Joshua J Beals

customer_reviews.title: This is really nice
customer_reviews.text: There are other less expensive models that you can get for $2.00 at Harbor Freight, but this one is loads ahead of those cheap ones. First off, on this one, you have access to 360 degrees of the magnesium stick. On the cheap ones, the magnesium stick is glued to an aluminum bar, so you end up wasting about 1/3 of the cheaper one any way, because you can't use what you can't strike. This one comes with some cotton wadding to use for tinder, and it comes in a water resistant case and a long lanyard, which means this entire unit remains in one piece. There is also a survival whistle, and a survival booklet. Top notch item.
customer_reviews.author: Tony Stompanado

customer_reviews.title: Excellent product for the price!
customer_reviews.text: PROS: Good size Lots of large sparks Tinder Compartment Whistle BG Survival Guide Inexpensive CONS: Has a material that you have to scrap off before it will spark. Lanyard is a bit awkward, and gets in the way of use. I cut mine off one side. Works great now. (Hopefully I won't lose the one side)
customer_reviews.author: Alyssa

customer_reviews.title: Got one for me and my dad!
customer_reviews.text: I live out in the country and I love chopping wood and having a campfire, something is very satisfying about it all. I like the authentic feel there is when I use this fire starter. I loved it so much, I knew my dad would as well, so I purchased him one as a Christmas gift. His eyes lite up! He is very into survival shows and it was perfect for him! He uses his to start little fires out back to sit by while he has his coffee
customer_reviews.author: FancyBell

customer_reviews.title: Compact, waterproof, works every time
customer_reviews.text: Lightweight and compact. The housing is waterproof. This is not the most heavy-duty fire starter on the market, but this puppy works every time no matter the conditions outside. Good value for the price.
customer_reviews.author: A.P.

customer_reviews.title: Solid product.
customer_reviews.text: Solid product. Im not the biggest fan of bear grylls and how his show trivialized outdoor skills...but he and gerber designed some great outdoor products. The knife and tool sharpener holds up as well as any lansky product i own.
customer_reviews.author: kris kiefert

customer_reviews.title: Practice makes perfect!
customer_reviews.text: You will see a few reviews saying this has a learning curve to it. It does but not a big one. It does throw a really hot spark and will do the job but if you havent used one before, go "back yard" camping and play/practice with it. Make a fire with it. Make another one then do it again so that you are familiar with this guy before you head out. One thing I didnt really like about it is that they lanyard seems a little short to me but then again im 6'4" and have big hands. YMMV. otherwise this is an inexpensive item to keep in your bag.
customer_reviews.author: Rene Ramirez

customer_reviews.title: You pay for the name
customer_reviews.text: Really not that great. I bought this remembering a little cheap fire starter I got for selling popcorn in the boy scouts way back when, and to be honest this doesn't measure up to that 30 cent piece of junk they gave me. Little pieces fell off the first time I took it apart, and it seems utterly impossible to make a nice big spark with it. The ergonomics just feel weird. I took it with me on a pike fishing trip to rainy lake, and I got so frustrated trying to light a fire so I could have a shore lunch that I tossed it in the lake. Ate nothing but cheetos and brita filtered water that day.
customer_reviews.author: Ben

customer_reviews.title: No instructions!!
customer_reviews.text: This works and is a valuable and well made tool - no doubt. But there are absolutely no instructions at all! There is a whole sheet of "survival instructions" that have nothing to do with this tool included. But a tool like this that requires very specific methods to make it work not having instructions included is very bad planning. I had to find a third party video on YouTube that sorta told how to use it. But, to be honest, I figured it out eventually by accident. I was about ready to return it out of frustration. I'm taking 2 stars away because of no instructions being included.
customer_reviews.author: Ron

customer_reviews.title: sturdy and works
customer_reviews.text: got this for my 13 year old. Took him a while to get the hang of it. Works really great if you just shave a bit into a leaf or bit of paper and then it lights very quickly. looks like it will last. hard to get the bottom off to access the cotton balls in the hidden compartment. Had one cotton ball included. Really starts a fire fast. and has a whistle.
customer_reviews.author: Mamamia

customer_reviews.title: Buy This One !!!
customer_reviews.text: I have purchased a few other ferro rod type fire starters and this is by far the easiest to start fire with and most comfortable to use. The striker has an ergonomic handle and throws a massive spark and some shavings to help the ignition of the tinder. Highly recommend this product for your camping/survival kit !!!
customer_reviews.author: Robert

customer_reviews.title: works great with very little effort
customer_reviews.text: I have had others but this one is way more compact and the strike produces sparks 1st or 2nd try. It takes only a little bit of practice to figure it out.
customer_reviews.author: Rand Whitney

customer_reviews.title: Great spark thrower
customer_reviews.text: I've bought the cheap add on magnesium fire starter that has a spark starter but for the life of me I cannot get that thing to throw sparks well. This Gerber fire starter throws huge sparks that catch kindling or magnesium easily. However I wish it did come with some of the magnesium starting material. The end cap comes off to store cotton and comes with a small ball of it tucked inside. There is also whistle which seems standard on these things and I guess in an emergency don't seem as annoying. Overall a great starter and I'll get many uses out of it.
customer_reviews.author: Kristi Lay

customer_reviews.title: Meh! Kind of bulky, difficult to use
customer_reviews.text: It looks great on paper, but when using it, I find this fire starter to be less than ideal. While it will produce sparks after the coating on the rod is removed even when wet, the sparks failed to ignite dry tinder. I tried cotton balls, cotton balls with petroleum jelly, dry leaves, and dry paper but the sparks aren't hot enough to ignite anything. I looked at various YouTube videos to see demonstrations and followed their procedures without any success. The rod is now completely shiny, and I spent over an hour outside trying to start a fire. Like the other Bear Grylls Gerber products, this was overrated. Overall: 2/5 stars.
customer_reviews.author: ChazTop Contributor: Golf

customer_reviews.title: Works well.
customer_reviews.text: Have tested it out and was able to start two fires with successfully. A friend said that the tinder compartment is small. Remember this is for emergency situation if primitive camping and for prepping you should have a source and storage of dried tinder already. I am happy with this product and comfortable to put in my hunting backpack in the emergency pouch section.
customer_reviews.author: Aaron

customer_reviews.title: Got a spark
customer_reviews.text: OK I've never used anything like this before, so it was a steep learning curve. I couldn't get a spark at first and was a bit frustrated but then I finally got a spark and another so I stopped being frustrated and felt very outdoorsy!
customer_reviews.author: MADianne

customer_reviews.title: Love it.
customer_reviews.text: Ferro-Rod w/ striker, Whistle, little bit of multi-inner-strand paracord, dry compartment for tinder, rescue signal directions printed right on the body. CAN YOU SAY MULTI-FUNCTIONAL. Feels sturdy and not a piece of poorly made plastic. Comes with a tiny printed basics of survival booklet (meh....) . I was going to get the following, but I think the gerber one does the job, includes more, for less money.  Edit: While analyzing every piece of kit in my bag for weight, I realized this thing packs a punch: 2.6 oz.... which is quite a bit for basically one job
customer_reviews.author: TurtleTop Contributor: Camping

customer_reviews.title: Wow!
customer_reviews.text: We tried this out in our Weber grill right after it arrived. Once you scrape off the black coating on the striking surface - this thing throws sparks easily and we were able to get a small fire going within 2 strikes. Haven't tried it out in the rain yet - but for dry fire-starting it's awesome.
customer_reviews.author: science_mom

customer_reviews.title: Recieved a cheap fake of the actual product !!
customer_reviews.text: I have used numerous fire starters throughout my military career and this is the worst! DO NOT BUY!Yet another knock off being sold on Amazon! I went to Walmart after noticing the paint not correctly on the bg indentations. Different cap. Orange O ring fell right off after opening... Compared mine to the actual real bear grylls and wow I received such a terrible fake! Cheap copy DO NOT BUT FROM THIS SELLER! better yet save yourself the headache and purchase it from Walmart for cheaper.
customer_reviews.author: Alex.k

customer_reviews.title: I really wanted to love this....
customer_reviews.text: First of all, its heavy. Not good for the ounce conscious. Second, it is difficult to strike with both ends on the same lanyard. Even when you remove one from it, the lanyard keeps flying around. It only strikes a spark about every 6th hit of the flint, which is daunting when you have a camp stove spewing gas everywhere & you're worried that it's taking too long. I would have returned this, but it is outside the return window due to my first scheduled trip being cancelled. It's so bad, that I will still have to carry matches/lighter to ensure that I have a reliable starter. DONT BUY
customer_reviews.author: Thomas Hawkins JR

customer_reviews.title: This one works!
customer_reviews.text: Every bugout bag's gotta have this. You need to have a way to start a fire to keep warm or to cook food. When the situation calls for it, you gotta have something that can get a fire going. This one works. A little cotton ball on one end is good for maybe like 2 or 3 fires. The only issues I have is I would have preferred a long lanyard so I can keep this around my neck. I also wish they had written instructions on how to use it. But you could always go to youtube and find the instructions there. Other than that, it's a must buy item for the preppers.
customer_reviews.author: Hardright

customer_reviews.title: Nice fire-starter. Good brand. Instructions would have been nice.
customer_reviews.text: Whistle, dry compartment, and flint stick all work well. My only gripe is that there is a black coating on the outside of the stick that has to be worn down before it produces sparks. There were no instructions that stated that, so I had to go online and make sure that the black coating was SUPPOSED to come off. It also would have been nice to have instructions telling you to pull the top of the key towards yourself when trying to get a spark. Also, getting the end of the dry compartment back on was a little tough and it's difficult to tell if it is back on correctly.
customer_reviews.author: BoilerNation

customer_reviews.title: Pretty good design
customer_reviews.text: Overall well designed. The strap was shorter than I had expected. Overall size small, hardly occupies any space. Whistle could be much better...not the one I'd want to depend on in an emergency. Insert (survival booklet) was a surprise. Having never used a striker before to start fires I thought I was using it wrong when I tried striking it a few times. You have to get through the coating on the rod and it'll work like a charm! This is going in my emergency bag in my car that I carry!
customer_reviews.author: T. A. Ernst

customer_reviews.title: Great fire starter under any conditions
customer_reviews.text: Put this in a bug out bag. Use it if I ever get stranded in my truck when I’m going to my second home in Arizona. Perfect for this use, or anywhere you need a fire under adverse conditions.
customer_reviews.author: emrescue

customer_reviews.title: Good product to have around for camping or just in case
customer_reviews.text: Product arrived quickly without any damage. Nice fire starter tool for camping or to have in your preparedness kit just in case. Has small container for tinder/cotton balls and an emergency whistle that could come in handy. Nice, practical product and good value!
customer_reviews.author: Katherine Hasal

customer_reviews.title: interesting
customer_reviews.text: This is my first fire starter of this type. It is pretty nice, but can't get the ball thing the string goes through back on after removing. My biggest complaint is that it seem excessively bulky for wilderness gear. Of course that shouldn't be a surprise by the picture. I still had that surprise a little when I got it in my hands. Also, seems it should facilitate the guide it comes with (like a clip to slide into since the guide is too large to go inside it, and that the guide should be laminated. I'd give it 3.5 stars if I could. "I like it" (4), but really just feel "it's OK "(3).
customer_reviews.author: um

customer_reviews.title: Embarrassed I kept this junk.
customer_reviews.text: Terrible design, very low quality, & utter failure as a tool. Survival with it undesirable.
customer_reviews.author: D.S.

customer_reviews.title: Bad Bear.
customer_reviews.text: Camping and hiking plus fishing lead us to want to cook in the great outdoors. We collect strikers as people "borrow" them all too frequently. We thought we would Bear G. fire starters a try. The built in whistle is functional as is the ferro rod. The strikers itself is pitiful and largely useless. We will use our Gerber carbon knife and make do. This was a test order. Too bad Bear gets a D.
customer_reviews.author: Kindle Customer

customer_reviews.title: Does a wonderful job of generating lots of sparks.
customer_reviews.text: This fire starter part itself is fantastic. Once you scrape through the rod coating you get a massive amount of sparks. The emergency whistle is a nice touch too. Two minor setbacks though. There is very little cavity space for storing tinder and the other setback is the short length of the para cord. Bar those two minor problems and it would get 5 stars instead of 4. The fire starting feature by itself is easily a 5 star winner but since they did include other features and you can't rate those features separately, I give this a "recommended buy" 4-star rating.
customer_reviews.author: Donald

customer_reviews.title: Works well!
customer_reviews.text: We started a fire with this the first day we received it. I had my boys outside and showed them how to use it; we then upgraded to using cotton balls soaked in Vaseline to prolong the fire starting ability of the fire starter. It works and I am not a survivalist nut living off the land cooking squirrels I shot with a home-made blow gun at 100 yards. I feel confident I could start a fire with this anywhere...and no, I don't watch Bear Gryllls on TV so I could care less who's name is on it...it works.
customer_reviews.author: Leesan

customer_reviews.title: Easiest to use firestarter.
customer_reviews.text: This fire starter is definitely the easiest of the flint & steel type starters I've used. The cap has a little bit of room for tinder/a cotton ball. I suggest soaking a bigger cotton ball with Vaseline (or any petroleum jelly) and stuffing it back in as tight as you can. This'll ensure the tender lasts longer and burns stronger. It takes a little practice to get working right, but in an emergency, which is what it's for, it gets the job done.
customer_reviews.author: Brax

customer_reviews.title: If you are looking for a fire starter, buy this one.
customer_reviews.text: This is the fire starter you want in the case of an emergency. I tried others and they are all in the trash. My only issue is with the short lanyard. Replace it with a longer length of 550 cord. If you are looking for a fire starter, buy this one. Remember to do what Bear Grylls does, bring a small bag of kindling with you when you go on those long hikes.
customer_reviews.author: David

customer_reviews.title: very well made
customer_reviews.text: unlike other products from Bear Grylls' survival series that are just cheap and marketing purposed-only, the fire starter is actually a multipurpose, Quality tool. the whistle is pretty darn loud and the flint shoots A LOT of sparks which is fantastic. the cotton ball container is a great idea. i just wish it was a little bigger. with that amount of cotton ball, you'll get a 5 seconds burning time. I impregnated the cotton ball with Vaseline and as a last resort option. highly recommend it and as Bear Grylls say, "super useful tool" :)
customer_reviews.author: J-man

customer_reviews.title: It Works
customer_reviews.text: My son and I started a fire out back using this and it worked like a charm. We didn't hike or camp with it, but it did what it was supposed to and sparked perfectly.
customer_reviews.author: Michael Kealey

customer_reviews.title: Fire Starter
customer_reviews.text: This fire starter is decent but has a few drawbacks. The rubber o-ring that appears to function as a seal when the starter is closed doesn't really serve its purpose. There is no pressure on the o-ring to form a seal because of how it's designed. Also, the o-ring is on the same piece as the striker and causes the o-ring to fall off when striking the rod. The lanyard is made of cheap material. Would be better to replace with paracord. The whistle feature is pretty cool and the Sparks created by the tool are pretty good.
customer_reviews.author: SandyAntny

customer_reviews.title: only good for back up
customer_reviews.text: good cool looking waterproof small tinder department whistle bad ferrocerium rod too small can't replace rod thick casing make this heavy after i got this product, went to friend's house and tried to set fire with friend. we liked the sparks and fire, but after few strokes, 1/5 rod is gone. haha purchased 15cm x 1.2cm ferrocerium rod for $8 this will last many years.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Don't forget to scrape the black off of the rod!
customer_reviews.text: Excellent firestarter. Compact, throws a ton of sparks. Love that it has a small container for tinder, and it includes a cotton ball. Whistle is meh but that's not why I bought this. Came with a neat little folding pocket guide with some useful survival information. Either scrape the black stuff off the rod, or give it a few hard strikes in the same location - you won't get sparks otherwise!
customer_reviews.author: tess

customer_reviews.title: Handy fire starter
customer_reviews.text: I was a bit skeptical about buying this. But since trying it out and seeing how much sparks it actually produces I was amazed. Paired with Zippo Easy Spark Tinders, I was able to get a fire going quickly. Since its a little bit larger than most fire starters its easier to hold onto to get good sparks with each strike.
customer_reviews.author: Arthur Frey

customer_reviews.title: Loud and Hot
customer_reviews.text: I made the mistake of really underestimating this thing. For the low cost I was not expecting much, especially from the cheap looking plastic whistle. So I had the dumb idea of trying this thing out in my garage. First off those sparks are hot. This thing works well, just about put a hole through the tarp I had in the garage, 2nd I made the mistake of blowing the whistle as loud as I could (indoors mind you) and I could not get rid of the ringing in my ears for about 15 minutes. I am very confident that this thing will work in any survival situation.
customer_reviews.author: Alexander Contreras

customer_reviews.title: Superior to the old style magnesium fire starter
customer_reviews.text: So I bought one of the magnesium bars with the flat metal scrapers, and never could get it to start a fire. However with this firestarter I was able to get a fire started in minutes. The key is that this tool will allow you to store dry kindling in the form of a cotton ball. That made all the difference for me! Given you get dry storage along with a nice lanyard, good ergonomics and a whistle, this is what you need. Don't bother with the old style silver bar. You try starting a fire with that and it'll crush your spirits when you really don't want your spirits crushed!
customer_reviews.author: Todd Justman

customer_reviews.title: Great emergency tool
customer_reviews.text: I haven't used it and only have it for emergencies on my day hikes, so I don't have a problem with the weight and I thought the cotton in there was thoughtful and nice. Stirke is very easy to achieve. The whistle is a good idea although I have one on my backpack. Bottom line is if something goes wrong this is a great idea to have so your not searching for dry sticks and brush you can rub together until your hands bleed. Thanks progress!
customer_reviews.author: KeeksTop Contributor: Photography

customer_reviews.title: Not completely what I expected...
customer_reviews.text: I have a strikeforce fire steel and thought this would be similar. While the "concept" is the same, the storage for tinder in this one is not what I expected. It is signficantly smaller than the Strikeforce. I like the idea of having a fire steel and tinder all in one package, but this package only provides the smallest amount of space, about half a cotton ball, for tinder storage. If I was only going to have one piece of tinder, it would be a wet fire, because of the burn time and it much more likely to get a fire going in wet conditions.
customer_reviews.author: Mikedave

customer_reviews.title: A Camping essential
customer_reviews.text: Great for camping. This generates a reliable spark once you get the hand of making it work, just avoid using in a breeze. Good to have some cotton or laundry lint available once you get a spark to get you started.
customer_reviews.author: DPR

customer_reviews.title: The rod will last a good long time before you really need another one
customer_reviews.text: Does the job. Little pricey but you can ignite it in any conditions. There is a high intensity spark the moment you strike. Remember, You need to peel of the black coat before you expose the shiny metal inside and generate the spark. The rod will last a good long time before you really need another one. I could find the tinder box (with small amount of tinder inside) after a while. Bonus: The survival booklet is very handy and useful. The whistle is super loud.
customer_reviews.author: TechieDEV

customer_reviews.title: This starter works when you need it
customer_reviews.text: I believe in having a real lighter in my survival kit, but bought this so I would be covered when my lighter failed or ran out of fuel. I built a few fires with this just so I would know how to use it if needed and it works great. First fire started with the first spark and first strike. If you have good tinder a little wind the shower of sparks from 1 strike gets you going. This one has a waterproof tinder compartment which is why I bought it, but it is tough built and easy to attach to your belt, knife sheath or backpack. well worth the money.
customer_reviews.author: Drummer 59

customer_reviews.title: Great Bear Grylls Product
customer_reviews.text: This is a great firesteel. For the record, I did not buy this because of the name on it, but rather I saw reviews on Youtube as well as here. You get the firesteel, a whistle, survival instructions and a small compartment to store tinder. As has been mentioned, the lanyard feels a little short, but that in no way stops one for operating this. For the price and the things included, there is no wonder this is one of the best sellers in the Bear Grylls lineup. I carry this in my backpack with me everyday.
customer_reviews.author: Alex C

customer_reviews.title: Great Fire Started
customer_reviews.text: This is a Great fire started throws off a bright white good sized spark I have tried it several times in different weather conditions using cotton balls infused with Vaseline and some with paraffin wax works great every time if you are not getting good results read the instructions and practice you wont be sorry and besides during an emergency is no time to lean how to use your gear it is solid and well built but I still subscribe to the military way of thinking if you have 2 you have 1 if you have one you have none during a crisis Murphys law is tripled so always have a spare
customer_reviews.author: Bodzila

customer_reviews.title: A good sparker but required more force than one would guess
customer_reviews.text: Takes a lot more force to get a decent shower of sparks than I would have guessed. However, with sufficient force, it does spark nicely. The ferro rod seems to wear down noticeably with a few uses - I immediately began wondering just how long this beauty would last under regular use. I found the only to reliable way to start a fire was to use Vaseline soaked cotton balls, but that may just be my low level of experience. Only got prepared tinder to catch once.
customer_reviews.author: Bob J.

customer_reviews.title: I was pleased he likes it
customer_reviews.text: I bought this for a stocking stuffer. Perfect for my husband. Thought it would be a great gag gift but he actually likes it.
customer_reviews.author: budicegirl247

customer_reviews.title: Don't laugh at it just because it's a Bear Grylls product - Good buy!
customer_reviews.text: First off, this thing feels very solid and well made. The fire starter itself works fine as I immediately tested it out. The whistle, albeit isn't loud, could help in a survival situation. This thing is waterproof. Just look up the youtube video testing it out. Also, the end that has the string going through it pops off and it has cotton inside to use as a fire starting material. There's room to add more if you want. I felt a little corny buying a Bear Grylls product but this thing is very good quality at a cheap price.
customer_reviews.author: A. Schmidt

customer_reviews.title: Great Product
customer_reviews.text: I was skeptical to buy this, as I am an avid backpacker who is not a fan of bear grills. I have use many magnesium fire starters and the bottom line is that this is the best one out there. The sparking blade is curved and when you hit it the right way you get a significantly better spark than any other product. It also has a cotton ball for tender in a small compartment for emergencies. The sparking blade is what makes this product so great.
customer_reviews.author: Bryan W

customer_reviews.title: always keep one in your pack
customer_reviews.text: This is my emergency fire starter for hikes/camping just in case, as a backup i always carry it in my pack. The construction isn't all that great, the two ends push together to cover the flint/striker, but mine didn't really seal well because the plastic was a bit warped. But it's not gonna affect the way it works so i'm still giving it a 5, as it could save a life someday.
customer_reviews.author: MalekoTop Contributor: Camping

customer_reviews.title: Easiest to use for adults and Cub Scouts
customer_reviews.text: I’m a Cub Scout den leader and used this to teach the fourth graders how to make a fire. This was by far the easiest spark-maker. Much easier than the ones brought by the other kids. Every kid was able to start a fire (we used dryer lint) with this one.
customer_reviews.author: L. Wixson

customer_reviews.title: Absolutely love it
customer_reviews.text: I bought one of these for myself and one for my dad for Father's Day last year and never really got around to trying it out. Finally got a chance to this last week and it worked great. Granted, it was at home in a controlled setting with a shredded up cotton ball, but it worked. The whistle is loud and takes no effort to blow, the little signals painted onto the casing are a nice touch, and the striker works great once you get the anti-corrosive coating off the stick. Throw in the fact it weighs almost nothing and you've got a great addition to any backpacking/hiker pack.
customer_reviews.author: Slamastack

customer_reviews.title: A great and easy fire starter
customer_reviews.text: I have not test it in a regular camping but I did it at home, Its work perfectly and can not see how it may not work out in the country, I would recommend to carry some material that ignite fast, this product produce a lot of sparks and it was very easy to use, beside the way to put it together is very safe. I think in my opinion one of the best fire starter in the market. I definitely recommend to camping friends.
customer_reviews.author: Eredu

customer_reviews.title: Simply a great ferro rod.
customer_reviews.text: Some of the Bear Grylls stuff gets made fun of, but not this one. Very well made and well thought out design. LARGE ferro rod that stores well with it's striker. Works very well to create great sparks, and has a small container for small tinder. What more can you ask for? A whistle you're asking for? Well you're in luck, they put a whistle on everything.
customer_reviews.author: Don E

customer_reviews.title: I found that this was the best rated one
customer_reviews.text: After reading many reviews, I found that this was the best rated one, and I can see why! It strikes really well and can be enclosed to protect it. You need to scrape off the black finish and get to the metal part before you can start seeing sparks.
customer_reviews.author: TaralynGoya

customer_reviews.title: Outstanding Product!!
customer_reviews.text: I now own two of these firesteels and believe they are the best on the market.. The sparks are plentiful and hot when you use the supplied built-in scraper. I have played around with these a lot and they ignite tinder better than other firesteels I have used.. Bear Grylls and Gerber did a great job on this one.. The firesteel is thick and should last a long time .. If you are thinking about getting one, do it, you will not regret it.. lots of quality features for the money..
customer_reviews.author: StampedeSurvival

customer_reviews.title: A must have for your survival kit.
customer_reviews.text: This is a great little fire starter. I have it in my pack along with weather proof matches, a disposable lighter, a zippo, and various flammables (like fuel cubes). There is a slight learning curve if you've never had to start a fire without matches, lighter, or accelerant. However, I was able to start a small fire on my kitchen counter (yep) my first try (I had to try it out). I wouldn't recommend it; the magnesium burns so hot that I now have little brown specks on my tile counter.
customer_reviews.author: dpidduck

customer_reviews.title: A medium-sparking emergency fire starter
customer_reviews.text: A good quality emergency firestarter. It seems very durable and even includes a survival whistle. And it you style to match the rest of the Bear Grylls survival series tools. It may not produce as many sparks and some other fire starters. But then again my technique may need a little bit of practice. It's just that I've seen others that produce more sparks. But this does make enough sparks to start a fire.
customer_reviews.author: R. Barnett

customer_reviews.title: Fire in Your Hands
customer_reviews.text: Got this as a Christmas gift for my brother, he really enjoyed playing with it. It has a small compartment where you can stick extra cotton balls in and a very loud emergency whistle that'll sure get someone's attention if you're ever lost. We tried the fire starter out in the backyard by using cotton and random bits of grass in a ceramic bowl to keep it contained. The flint made quite a spark and lit that pile of cotton and grass quickly.
customer_reviews.author: Jennifer

customer_reviews.title: Works very well
customer_reviews.text: Works great. Once you scrape off the black coating this thing looks like you lit a sparkles every time you strike it. I can usually get a fire going within 3 strikes. Bought 2 and both work the same!
customer_reviews.author: Zach A

customer_reviews.title: Good product. Good price.
customer_reviews.text: The piece of paracord is too short for it to be used anywhere except maybe a wrist or backpack. I just replaced it with a longer one to go around my neck. The whistle is loud and high pitched. Good sparks. I don't like orange but I get it. It's easier to see if you drop it. The space for tinder is nice. Just put a piece of cotton for emergencies. I haven't tried any other ones out there so I can't compare.
customer_reviews.author: Joe

customer_reviews.title: Actually Works
customer_reviews.text: I am a sucker for trying new stuff. I thought this would be crap. However, it works really good. I was so impressed a purchased a few more to give as gifts. I think these are perfect to keep in the RVs.
customer_reviews.author: Investigator

customer_reviews.title: I love the handle
customer_reviews.text: I love the handle. However, I finally tried this and a starter I bought for $1 and they worked the same. The Gerber starter is easier to hold because of the handle, and this whistle and small compartment come in handy. I keep a cotton ball with petroleum jelly in it for tinder.
customer_reviews.author: Kat Loveless

customer_reviews.title: Big Spark
customer_reviews.text: First you scratch off the manufacturing black soot from the rod. Then it is easy to make a large spark from the given scratcher blade. Either side is effective. Give enough pressure and speed to the blade. I started several fires from the enclosed cotton balls, from cotton given with medicine bottles, feather down (the down on the lower part of feathers), old mattress padding, etc. Build it up with shredded paper/cardboard etc., upto twiggs and wood. Pretty easy. Water proof cap to store small amout of fire starter material. Good purchase...
customer_reviews.author: R. SAFRENOTop Contributor: Pets

customer_reviews.title: If only mom had named me "Bear"...
customer_reviews.text: Bulbous gimmick heavy piece of cr*p. Dull striker. Stupid graphics dots show how to dot-dot-dot, dash dash... Holy hoakey.
customer_reviews.author: Terry  Lynn Harris

customer_reviews.title: Love all things Gerber!
customer_reviews.text: I got this for my father for Christmas because he is a hunter and is always by himself in the woods. I worry that he could somehow become stranded and not have cell service or resources to heat. I worry a little less with this as it really strikes a huge spark and also houses a place for dry cotton. It also has a whistle in case help is needed. He straps this to his deer stand and it gives me a peace of mind.
customer_reviews.author: Brenton1985

customer_reviews.title: not even a spark
customer_reviews.text: The compartment for cotton is on there super tight (which is good). All together feels great. Just one problem, it doesn't work. It won't even throw a spark, no matter the strength. I even tried a different striker...still nothing. Guess I got a lemon? :( I'm getting a refund and they're letting me keep it...even though it doesn't create a spark.
customer_reviews.author: Barbara

customer_reviews.title: Great fire Starter!
customer_reviews.text: It starts fires! I also enjoy having the whistle, I've had to use it on the water before for kayaking, and it is rather loud! The fire starter does take skill to use, do not think that you can just pull this thing out and start a fire. So take some time and practice. I use cotton balls to start most of my fires, and it's worked just great! I also love the fact that it closes up and I can throw it in my deck bag and not worry about it getting wet. Over all, it's fantastic. I'm really happy with this.
customer_reviews.author: S. Ross Allen

customer_reviews.title: great product
customer_reviews.text: I like this product. It came exactly as advertised. The waterproof compartment for kindling is excellent. It seems very durable and i have used it to start a handful of fires. I did accidentally leave it in my backpack in the airport and had to be frisked by tsa though LOL
customer_reviews.author: Sean

customer_reviews.title: Great product!
customer_reviews.text: I recieved this product today (earlier than expected) and immediately took it outside to give it a try. It is very sturdy and seems like it will last for a long time. I don't have alot of experience using a fire starter but I had no trouble at all getting a nice fire going. The starter produces alot of sparks with little effort and I love that the lanyard keeps everything together. It has a very small place to keep tinder which could be little larger but this isn't really a big deal. Overall a great product. Will be ordering another one to keep with camping gear as I plan on keeping this one in my pack.
customer_reviews.author: renee27

customer_reviews.title: much larger then i thought. handle is okay
customer_reviews.text: Much larger then i thought. the handy pocket sheet gives u nice illustrations and tips on survival. the item itself is much larger then I thought. the rod itself works just fine. just a few strokes will peel the black paint off and you will have great sparks. not bad for price but id go for something more compact next time.
customer_reviews.author: Khalil

customer_reviews.title: Oh yeah, some serious sparks!
customer_reviews.text: These are significantly better then some others I've purchased. These definitely throw up some serious sparks. The end that you scrape on (Name?) is painted black. You need to scrape through the black to begin seeing sparks. It's not that hard to do and once you do, you have some serious sparks coming out when you scrape. I tried it out in my garage, and had to open the door and vent the smell out. It's happily in my emergency supply, and I'm glad I bought it.
customer_reviews.author: XraysJL

customer_reviews.title: It works!
customer_reviews.text: As making fire goes, a lighter or matches are the obvious choice. Keeping one of these in each of your vehicles and in your camping gear can be a real life-saver and works in a pinch. I like the idea of it so much, I bought a couple more. After you figure out how to use it, there isn't much difficulty starting a fire if you know how to make a fire. With a little coaching, my wife was able to start a fire and she is not an out-doors kind of person at all. If you get good at using this, it will make hundreds of fires for you.
customer_reviews.author: Jonathan Smith

customer_reviews.title: Strong and sturdy. Great great product
customer_reviews.text: The black coating that makes it difficult to strike comes off eventually after a few strikes, so yes it does become easier to strike. Waterproof, the lanyard keeps from keeping each end from getting lost. And there is a small area on one end that you can use to put fire starting material. Small enough for a small cotton ball, which it actually comes with, Small bonus! Also doubles as a whistle. Strong and sturdy. Great great product.
customer_reviews.author: Johnson America

product_meta.title: Gerber Bear Grylls Fire Starter [31-000699]
product_meta.description:
AMAZON.COM
The product of collaboration between Gerber and survival expert Bear Grylls, the Survival Series Fire Starter is a must-have for scouting, camping, and hiking expeditions. Small and compact, this fire starter offers years of use. Watertight construction keeps tinder safe and dry, so when you need it, you can trust that it's ready to use.



Bear Grylls and Gerber Team Up
The Fire Starter is part of the Gerber Bear Grylls Survival Series of gear. This collaboration brings together Gerber's 70+ years of knife and gear expertise with Bear Grylls's extensive outdoor survival and adventure experience to create a one-of-a-kind line of knives, tools, and gear.From spending time in the British SAS, to scaling Mount Everest, Bear knows what it takes to be a survivor in extreme situations and multiple environments. Now he brings that knowledge to the creation of a range of items that help you make the most of your outdoor adventures.

Get a Fire Going Quickly and Safely
The Fire Starter contains everything you need to get a fire going--simply pull the unit apart. It features a ferrocerium rod and a metal striker, as well as a waterproof storage compartment to keep tinder dry.

A lanyard keeps each piece of the product secure while it's open, and has an integrated emergency whistle for quick access when you need it.



Lightweight Design for Easy Portability
Measuring 4-4/5 inches when closed, with a weight of 2-3/5 ounces, the Fire Starter fits neatly into a backpack or gear bag. It is a self-contained, waterproof unit that can be easily converted into a fire-starting kit by pulling the two ends apart.Includes Bear Grylls' Pocket Survival Guide
This tool comes with land to air rescue instructions and BearGrylls' informative Priorities of Survival pocket guide, loaded with survival basics designed to help keep you alive until you can be rescued or rescue yourself.

What's in the Box
Fire starter kit with starter, rod, and lanyard, and pocket survival guide.







FROM THE MANUFACTURER
Gerber 31-000699 fire starter is small and compact. The fire starter offers years of use. Watertight construction keeps tinder safe and dry, so when you need it, you can trust it. Features include compact fire starter with ferrocerium rod and metal striker, lanyard to keep product secure and together, emergency whistle integrated into lanyard cord, waterproof storage compartment for tinder, and land to air rescue and SOS instructions. It has a priorities of survival pocket guide that contains Bear's survival essentials, and the overall length is 4.8 inches.
